Research Article Lithium nitride (Li3N) formation in lithium-mediated electrochemical ammonia synthesis can be enhanced with the right proton donor Victor Azumah Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a Lance Kavalsky Writing – review & editing Supervision Software Conceptualization b Venkatasubramanian Viswanathan Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization c b ⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan Ann Arbor MI 48109 USA o=Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan, c=Ann Arbor, s=MI,sp=, p=48109, cy=USA b Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Michigan Ann Arbor MI 48109 USA o=Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Michigan, c=Ann Arbor, s=MI,sp=, p=48109, cy=USA c Department of Aerospace Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA Department of Aerospace Engineering, University of Michigan Ann Arbor MI 48109 USA o=Department of Aerospace Engineering, University of Michigan, c=Ann Arbor, s=MI,sp=, p=48109, cy=USA ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA. Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Michigan Ann Arbor MI 48109 USA Lithium-mediated electrochemical ammonia synthesis (LiMEAS) hinges on the formation of lithium nitride (Li3N) from dissociated nitrogen at a lithium surface. Although proton donors (PDs) are known to influence nitrogen activation, their specific role in promoting Li3N formation is still being investigated. Herein, we employ density functional theory (DFT) to examine the effects of 17 PDs on the stability and energetics of Li3N formation. We show that in the absence of PD, Li3N formation is consistently outcompeted by subsurface N2 embedding and, in some cases, by surface N2 adsorption. However, the introduction of PD species yields three distinct outcomes: (i) the PD remains intact during Li3N formation, (ii) the PD protonates Li3N, or (iii) the PD undergoes structural change. Notably, configurations in which the PD remains intact exhibited greater stability compared to subsurface embedding, driven by PD-induced surface reconstruction. We quantify this reconstruction using a two-layer displacement metric and find a strong correlation between the magnitude of displacement and the system’s overall stability. Further charge analyses show that the enhanced Li3N stability correlates with a greater electron transfer to nitrogen. Finally, we link the basicity, acidity and polarity of PD with the results of the formation of nitride, demonstrating that the basicity of PD promotes intact configurations Li3N. In contrast, higher acidity and polarity lead to protonation and alteration of PD. These insights pinpoint a region in the Kamlet–Taft β – π space where PDs remain intact and foster stable Li3N, informing future strategies to design more efficient LiMEAS systems. Graphical abstract Keywords Electrochemical ammonia synthesis Lithium-mediated nitrogen reduction Nitrogen dissociation Density functional theory Proton donor Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia production contributes approximately 1%–2% to global greenhouse gas emissions, primarily due to the energy-demanding Haber–Bosch process—a process that has recently become a prime target for electrification efforts [1–10]. Among the many electrochemical strategies proposed to replace this conventional method, metal nitride-mediated synthesis has emerged as particularly promising, mainly because lithium acts as the principal electrocatalyst, yielding enhanced Faradaic efficiencies. This approach, known as lithium-mediated electrochemical ammonia synthesis (LiMEAS), consistently delivers current efficiencies exceeding 60% while achieving robust ammonia production yields [11–14]. The LiMEAS process unfolds through three main stages: (i) electrodeposition of lithium onto a substrate (Eq. (1)), (ii) generation of a lithium nitride film via the dissociation of molecular nitrogen (Eq. (2)), and (iii) subsequent hydrogenation of the nitride by a proton donor, which releases ammonia and regenerates lithium ions (Eq. (3)). The overall electrochemical reaction can be summarized as follows: (1) Li + (aq) + e − → Li (s) (2) 3 Li (s) + 1 2 N 2 ( g ) → Li 3 N (s) (3) Li 3 N (s) + 3H + (aq) → 3Li + (aq) + NH 3 (g) (4) 1 2 N 2 ( g ) + 3 ( H + + e − ) → NH 3 (g) With the realization of a full-cell proof-of-concept [15–18], lithium’s capacity to cleave the robust triple bond in nitrogen at near-ambient conditions has been demonstrated to be central to this process’ success [19–23]. In particular, lithium-induced splitting of the nitrogen molecule competes with the hydrogen evolution reaction, the primary side reaction that diminishes Faradaic efficiency [24,25]. These enhancements in both activity and selectivity give LiMEAS a distinct advantage over previous electrochemical methods for ammonia synthesis, which have long been hampered by poor selectivity [14,22,23,25–30]. However, even with LiMEAS’s impressive current and Faradaic efficiency, there are challenges to increasing the cyclability and overall yield of the system [11,12,31,32]. Electrolyte design and cathode material modifications have emerged as powerful levers to optimize LiMEAS further. For example, Jeon et al. have shown that incorporating Ag into a copper cathode significantly enhances ammonia production by promoting the formation of LiF and Ag–Li alloys within the SEI, thereby reducing Li plating overpotentials—especially in fluorine-containing electrolytes [33]. In parallel, Li et al. demonstrated that a chain ether-based solvent, with its high boiling point (162, °C) and non-polymerizing properties, supports a compact SEI on the gas diffusion electrode, allowing 300h continuous operation at room temperature and 1bar pressure with a current-to-ammonia efficiency of 64% and a gas-phase ammonia content of approximately 98% [34]. Further advancing our understanding, Chang et al. emphasized the catalytic role of the SEI by systematically analyzing its chemical species and reaction pathways, linking its composition to improved product selectivity and kinetics in LiNRR [35]. Electrolyte engineering has also proven to be effective: Liu et al. replaced tetrahydrofuran with 1,2-diethoxyethane (DEE), which weakens interfacial passivation and induces a general corrosion behavior that nearly doubles the Faradaic efficiency (from 33.4% to 61.7%) [36]. Similarly, investigations by Cai et al. into ether-based solvents revealed that dimethoxyethane minimizes potential losses, while tetrahydrofuran achieves a faradaic efficiency of 58.5 ± 6.1% at ambient pressure by affecting ion solvation and SEI composition [37]. Additionally, Iriawan et al. found that an upshift in the Li + /Li potential – attained using more dissociative lithium salts at higher concentrations – correlates with improved ammonia production stability and efficiency through beneficial modifications in the SEI (notably enriched with LiF and LiOEt species) [38]. Finally, Fu et al. provided systematic information on the influence of lithium salt selection in a continuous flow reactor, identifying lithium tetrafluoroborate (LiBF 4 ) as the optimal salt to achieve ammonia selectivity 61%, while lithium bis (trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) underperformed due to catalyst poisoning [39]. When designing an electrolyte for LiMEAS, the choice of proton donor (PD) is crucial, as it notably influences the morphology of the interface [40]. In particular, the Kamlet–Taft (KT) parameters have been correlated with nitrogen reduction activity [41]. Investigations of PD behavior have revealed that while an optimal PD can enhance interface morphology and improve Faradaic efficiency, exceeding a certain threshold can lead to excessive hydrogen evolution, undermining ammonia synthesis [42]. Initially regarded solely as a source of protons to drive nitrogen reduction — and thus a tool to modulate hydrogen evolution through its availability and dissociation characteristics [15,16]—recent studies have also explored the potential of proton shuttles [11] and proton donors with intermediate dissociation strengths [43]. Emerging findings indicate that the role of PD in shaping interfacial morphology may extend beyond merely supplying protons; its involvement in the formation of lithium nitride remained an open question [32,40,42]. We note that experimental studies, including Du et al. [44], have demonstrated the sensitivity of LiMEAS performance to proton donor identity. However, reactor conditions and electrolyte composition can lead to widely divergent results even for the same proton donor species. Our first-principles calculations aim to complement these studies by isolating and clarifying the atomic-scale mechanisms, specifically how proton donor chemistry influences lithium surface structure and nitride formation stability, providing a molecular-level framework for interpreting and guiding experimental findings. However, experimental investigations of proton donor effects are complicated by the interplay of reactor design, electrolyte properties, gas diffusion, and operational parameters, which can confound intrinsic mechanistic interpretations. Thus, a systematic first-principles approach is valuable to isolate the fundamental atomic-scale interactions underpinning lithium nitride formation and nitrogen reduction. While the formation of lithium nitride is assumed to be spontaneous, previous work on lithium nitridation shows that even in the presence of pure metallic lithium, nitride formation is not spontaneous under dry conditions and requires facilitation due to the presence of a humid environment, or elevated temperatures or pressures [19]. This finding, in addition to similar findings of improvements in LiNRR efficiencies in the presence of water and oxygen [45,46]. These works suggest that lithium nitride formation is highly influenced by the local environment within which the nitrogen interacts with the lithium surface. However, we found no prior work exhaustively probed this hypothesis. In our previous work, we began to bridge this knowledge gap by demonstrating that PD affects the strength of nitrogen adsorption on the lithium slab, revealing two proton-free nitrogen configurations with substantially stronger interactions and identifying a thermodynamically favorable path to formation Li3N from PD-induced N2 [47]. Herein, we build on this finding by investigating the effects of PD on Li3N formation and exploring how PD influences the process following dissociation. Utilizing density-functional theory (DFT) calculations, we demonstrate that Li3N formation after the dissociation of N2 on the surface is less favored compared to processes like N2 subsurface embedding. However, the presence of PD may lead to the formation of more stable Li3N in scenarios where proton transfer or PD decomposition did not occur. This increased favorability of Li3N formation in the presence of PD was consistent across all 17 PDs studied, which were selected to represent the KT space. We further show that the creation of these stable Li3N configurations results from PD-induced surface reconstruction. Charge and correlation analyses indicate a strong dependence of nitrogen reduction on this induced reconstruction, and further analyses elucidate the integral role of PD in Li3N formation by establishing direct connections to its chemistry. Thus, our work underscores the importance of PD in influencing nitride formation at the atomic level. 2 Methods 2.1 Computational parameters Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out with GPAW within the Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE) framework [48,49]. The structures were generated through the AutoCat software package and relaxed until the atomic forces fell below a convergence threshold of 0.05 eV/Å [50]. The Bayesian Error Estimation Functional with van der Waals correlation (BEEF-vdW) was employed to model electron–electron exchange–correlation interactions. A finite difference method was used with a grid spacing of 0.16 Å, along with a 4 × 4 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack k-point grid to sample the Brillouin zone of the surfaces. To improve the convergence of the self-consistent field (SCF) algorithm, electron occupations were smeared using the Fermi-Dirac method with a width of 0.05 eV. Adsorbates were positioned on one side of the slab, and a dipole correction was applied accordingly. Slabs were chosen to be 3 × 3 × 4 with the bottom 2 layers fixed and top 2 layers allowed to move. 2.2 Lithium nitride formation baseline In this work, we study the adsorption energetics of two nitrogen atoms on the Li(100) slab, which was chosen as prior work showed that nitrogen adsorption was strongest on this facet [47]. This step serves to provide a fundamental understanding of the thermodynamics of nitride formation after nitrogen molecule dissociation and to set a baseline for which subsequent studies can be compared. Nitrogen atoms were placed 1.5 Å above the slab, well within the bond length (1.927 Å) predicted by our bulk relaxations and in agreement with prior literature [51]. Here we restricted the initial placement of both atoms to the same kind of symmetry site to reduce the combinatorics. For this bcc100 surface, the three symmetry site types are ontop, bridge, and hollow. To explore the potential energy landscape, the two atoms were also placed at nearest neighbor (NN) symmetry sites and next nearest neighbor (NNN) sites, with each configuration having placements at the respective symmetry sites as shown in (Fig. 1a). We will compare this to the minimum energy of different orientations of the nitrogen molecule N2 at the same sites to assess the thermodynamic drive from adsorption to nitride. The adsorption energy between the nitrogen atoms and the slab, which we will define as the nitride formation (NF) energy, is calculated via: (5) where E 2 N is the surface nitride formation energy, n the number of nitrogen atoms, E s l a b − 2 N is the DFT energy of the two nitrogen atoms (N) on the lithium slab, E s l a b is the energy of the lithium slab alone, and is the DFT energy of an isolated nitrogen molecule. For the nitrogen molecule, the adsorption energy is calculated using a similar scheme to Eq. (5) as: (6) Here we define the DFT energy of a nitrogen molecule ( ) adsorbed on the lithium slab as . 2.3 Lithium nitride formation in the presence of a proton donor (PD) The effects of the proton donor on formation are studied in the two neighborhood schemes NN and NNN by placing the PD halfway between the two nitrogen atoms (Fig. 1b). Each PD was initially placed much further from the slab at 3 Å. However, PD interaction ability is maximized by using the most electrophilic atom (determined by charge analysis) as the placement anchor, and each symmetry site is explored, consistent with our established scheme. Drawing from the insights established by previous literature showing the PD’s Kamlet–Taft (KT) parameters to be indicators of LiMEAS, we select our PDs to span over each quadrant of the KT space (Fig. 1c) [41]. To allow for variety in the exploration of the PD’s effects on the surface nitride formation landscape, three different configurations are generated for each PD, each one having the PD uniquely aligned along the x-, y-, or z -axis. This means that for each PD, we have 3 unique sites, 3 orientations, and 2 neighbor schemes, resulting in 18 calculations per PD. As the presence of the PD introduces another layer of interaction into our system, the energy between the components is the interaction energy which is calculated using: (7) where E i n t is the interaction energy, E s l a b − P D − 2 N is the DFT energy of the model system, E s l a b is the energy of the pristine lithium slab, and E P D and E N 2 represent the energies of the isolated proton donor and the isolated nitrogen molecule respectively. When the PD is absent from the model, the interaction energy is equivalent to the NF energy in Eq. (5). Thus, to allow a comparison of the PD-calculated interaction energies with the NF energies set by the baseline, the energy of the final configuration is obtained after removing the PD. Eq. (5) is used to calculate the NF energy of the PD-induced nitride structure. 2.4 Geometric analysis and dimensionality reduction To understand the nature of the underlying nitride structures and their similarities and differences, structural analysis was performed on all final configurations after the PD was removed, allowing them to be compared to the baseline nitrides. This analysis was done by encoding each structure using DScribe’s Smooth Overlap of Atomic Positions (SOAP) descriptor, interfacing with our in-house AutoCat software, to obtain vectors of fixed length [48,49,52–57]. We then perform dimensionality reduction on these structure encodings of the slab to two dimensions via the Uniform Manifold Approximation Projection (UMAP) algorithm [58]. Any subsequent clustering after identifying unique and recurring themes is done with the HDBSCAN clustering algorithm [59]. 2.5 Statistical analysis and significance testing All statistical analyses were performed using the Pingouin statistical package in Python [60]. Pearson’s product-moment correlation coefficients (r values) were computed to quantify the strength and direction of linear relationships between numerical descriptors—including surface reconstruction metrics, interaction energies, nitride formation energies, and proton donor (PD) chemical parameters. The r value ranges from −1 to 1, where 1 indicates a perfect positive linear correlation, −1 indicates a perfect negative linear correlation, and 0 indicates no linear relationship. Correlation strength was interpreted as follows: nonexistent for —r— between 0.0 and 0.3, weak between 0.3 and 0.5, moderate between 0.5 and 0.7, strong between 0.7 and 0.9, and near-perfect above 0.9. The statistical significance of correlations was assessed using two-tailed tests at a significance level of α = 0.05. The associated p value represents the probability of observing a correlation as extreme as the computed r value under the null hypothesis of no relationship. Correlations were considered statistically significant when p < 0 . 05 , regardless of the absolute magnitude of r. The blue shaded regions in correlation plots represent the 95% confidence intervals of the linear regression fit, calculated from the standard error of the regression, and indicate the range within which the true regression line is expected to fall with 95% confidence. To assess the dependence of DFT-induced numerical changes on the categorical variable of proton donor identity, one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) tests were performed. In these analyses, the numerical descriptor was treated as the dependent variable, while proton donor identity served as the independent factor. A p -value less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Where significant differences were detected, no post hoc comparisons were conducted, as the objective was to determine the existence of dependency rather than to resolve individual groupwise differences. Normality and homogeneity of variances were assumed for all statistical tests unless otherwise indicated. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Nitride formation on the lithium slab As the goal of this work is to understand formation in the context of LiMEAS, we start with a simplified model of the system, abstracting the interactions of all the components that are generally present in experiments and allowing us to focus on the thermodynamics of isolated surface nitride formation. Primarily, we aim to isolate the behavior of PD-2N when it is present in the presence of lithium alone, with an extension to SEI surfaces reserved for a future study. Motivating this approach, we note that the continuous deposition employed in LiNRR does not preclude the existence of metallic Li, even in the presence of an SEI [31,61,62]. Additionally, both within the field of LiNRR and in general studies of lithium-metal batteries, where SEI plays a role, excluding SEI to focus solely on metallic lithium behaviors facilitated theoretical insights into probing the influence of lithium metal on system interactions [37,47,62–66]. With this baseline model, we can begin to add complexity to our system with the introduction of the PD to understand then how its presence changes the interaction. From our most straightforward model, we relaxed the two nitrogen atoms on the 100 facet of the lithium slab, opting for two neighborhood configurations, a nearest neighbor (NN) placement and a next nearest neighbor (NNN) placement at all three unique symmetry sites (Fig. 1a). For the 100 surface, these are the ontop site, where each nitrogen atom sits directly on a lithium atom; the bridge site, where each nitrogen atom sits in between two lithium atoms directly adjacent to each other; and the hollow site, where the nitrogen atom sits at the four-fold coordination point between surface lithium atoms. With three sites and two neighborhood configurations, this resulted in six calculations. For all of these sites, we also investigated the adsorption of the nitrogen molecule N2 as well as the thermodynamics of its subsurface embedding across 3 axis-oriented configurations. We then compared the minimum energy for N2 adsorption and subsurface embedding at each site with the surface nitride formation energy at the same site as shown in Fig. 2(a–b). With the initial placement well within the bond length of bulk and the initial distance between nitrogen atoms at or greater than the lithium lattice constant (3.32 Å), we expected all configurations to form some nitride system, with each nitrogen atom coordinating with their own set of lithium atoms. We found that the relaxed configurations for all but one system are consistent with these expectations. In the NN placement at the ontop site, we find that the two nitrogen atoms recombine into the nitrogen molecule despite an initial separation distance of more than 300% the bond length (1.097 Å). Considering the energetics of the system in Fig. 2a, we see that the formation of at the ontop site is thermodynamically unfavorable with initial placement at the NN site. Even with initial placements at the hollow and bridge site, where surface nitride formation is thermodynamically favorable, our results show that adsorption is energetically preferred to surface nitride formation at the three sites, although the subsurface N2 is by far the most dominant process. However, with initial nitrogen atom placement at the NNN sites, surface nitride formation at the bridge and hollow sites become more thermodynamically favored over N2 adsorption at the same sites, although again at the top site adsorption is stronger than surface nitride formation. However, this improvement within the NNN scheme is not enough to displace subsurface N2 formation as the most thermodynamically favored process. That surface nitride formation gets more favored over adsorption within the NNN scheme suggests that favorable formation, at least on the 100 facet, requires significant nitrogen atom diffusion ( 2 × the lattice constant) across the slab to occur. This would require multiple site-hopping steps, which may lead to a more significant kinetic barrier towards surface nitride formation. Either way, the strong thermodynamic drive towards subsurface N2 formation suggests a propensity towards interactions with the lithium bulk. However, this need not be inhibitive to the formation of nitride, as the existing literature examining the dissociation of N2 reveals a subsurface N2 transition state, suggesting that subsurface N2 formation could be a precursor to Li3N formation [50,66]. 3.2 Proton donor (PD) effects on formation After establishing a baseline understanding of how forms in the absence of the PD, we next introduce different PDs into our model to probe their effect on surface nitride formation thermodynamics. Consistent with our established model for surface nitride formation, we explore the impact of the presence of PD on all symmetrically relevant sites in two neighborhood regimes (Fig. 1b). Here, we introduce variance to our PD effects and increase our sampling of the energy landscape by modeling three different axis-aligned PD orientations for each site-neighborhood configuration considered. This allows us to probe for consistent effects within and across PDs and enables a more systematic probing of their effects on surface nitride formation. 3.2.1 Proton donor selection We selected 17 PDs to use in our model as their chemical identity could have significant and varying effects on the formation of the underlying nitride. For this work, it was important that the PDs selected were both field-relevant and varied enough to establish different chemical environments around the nitrogen atoms. The Kamlet–Taft selection criterion for the effects of PD identity on LiMEAS activity established by previous work [41] provides such a guide for PD selection. That work unveiled that PDs with high Kamlet–Taft α and β showed activity towards LiMEAS when tested, whereas those in the three red quadrants were inactive. Thus, drawing from the insights established by previous literature showing that PD Kamlet–Taft (KT) parameters are indicators of LiMEAS activity, we select our PDs to span each quadrant of the KT space, including linear aliphatic alcohols such as ethanol and butanol, shuttle-type PDs such as phenol and solvent species tetrahydrofuran (Fig. 1c). Here, α measures the strength of hydrogen bond donating (proton-donating) [67], β measures the strength of hydrogen bond accepting (basicity) [68], and π ∗ captures the solvent polarity effects [69]. These parameters provide a chemical framework for understanding how proton donors may influence surface interactions, electron transfer, and ammonia production efficiency. Furthermore, due to speculation that tetrahydropyran could be a viable candidate to reduce the effects of SEI impermeability, it was included as a PD of interest [42]. For a complete list of the species explored, refer to the Supplementary Material. In the following sections, we discuss structural and thermodynamic trends observed across PDs and insights into PD effects obtained from a combination of charge and statistical analysis. 3.2.2 structures evolved in the presence of PD Completing geometric relaxations with the PD present resulted in a bifurcation in themes seen across PDs pertaining to the lithium slab and the behavior of nitrogen atoms and the PD. The themes relating to PD behavior are primarily an indication of the PD’s end state in the final configuration. This serves as an indicator of the PD’s ability to facilitate Li3N formation without engaging in adverse interactions. This was done to ensure consistency across configurations that were used in downstream analysis. We classify final proton donor (PD) behaviors into three categories based on their interaction with the lithium–nitrogen system: “Intact”, where the PD remains chemically unchanged while stabilizing the formation of the expected Li3N (Fig. 2c); “Protonated”, where the PD transfers a proton to Li3N, altering the chemistry of both the PD and the nitride; and “Altered”, where the PD undergoes decomposition or reacts with nitrogen to form N-derivative species. These outcomes are analyzed in detail in later sections for their practical implications in LiMEAS, particularly regarding their influence on system stability, electron transfer, and the efficiency of nitride formation. Furthermore, the evolution of these themes suggests that events such as protonation of Li3N by PD are not purely sequential events but can occur concurrently with nitride formation, providing a pathway for early stage NH3 release without requiring full decomposition of the PD. This indicates that certain PDs may simultaneously stabilize Li3N and act as effective proton sources, a dual function relevant for the practical design of LiMEAS. In Fig. 2c, we see that both the Intact and Altered grouping have a higher occurrence than the Protonated grouping. Looking at the minimum energy configuration for each PD, we show in Fig. 2d the number of groupings possible within each PD and the proportion of minimum energy configurations corresponding to a particular grouping. We find that if only one grouping was possible for a PD, it was equally likely (proportion = 0.5) that the PD would remain intact, resulting in the expected Li3N configuration or be altered, resulting in decomposition. This suggests that there exist PDs for which surface nitride formation is the only possible interaction between Li, 2N atoms, and the PD. In contrast, there are also PDs for which decomposition of the PD itself is the only expected route. We find this to hold true for both the NN and NNN schemes (Fig. S1). When two states were possible, the proportion of the Altered PDs remained the same at 0.5, with the Intact PDs ceding some proportion to the Protonated group as the most energetically favorable configuration. We assert this to be the case as Fig. S1d shows that for our data, the protonated nitride configuration was thermodynamically favored over the nonprotonated Li3N nitride configuration (with Intact PD) whenever the only two possible PD outcomes were Intact and Protonated regardless of the neighborhood scheme. Although it appears that the formation of protonated nitride thermodynamically dominates the other two in the NN scheme whenever it was possible (fig. S1e), that is not the case for the NNN scheme where our analysis in fig. S1f. Thus, we cannot yet rule out the importance of Li3N formation accompanied by Altered PD. However, here we confine our dataset to the expected Li3N configurations where the PD remains intact, as they allow for an unambiguous one-to-one comparison with our established baseline. Fig. 2c shows adequate neighborhood representation in all our datasets, allowing statistical analyses to be performed on both types of neighborhood. Using our Intact dataset, we explore the themes derived from the lithium slab behavior, using SOAP to encode the slab, created after the PD was removed, into vectors. These encoded vectors are then visualized in two-dimensional space using UMAP, encouraging the localization of similar structures by minimizing the distance between points and allowing structures sufficiently far from each other to be considered a group. The resulting structures were assigned arbitrary labels based on their clustering in two-dimensional space and before label updates were given based on similarities in qualitative behavior. To understand these projected clusters, we consider the average surface nitride formation energies (E(Li-2N)) of each cluster (Table S1). We then confirm the similarity between the in-group structures through manual visual inspection. Combining these two methods, we find that clusters of unique structures display an absolute deviation in their mean surface nitride formation energy of less than 0.1 eV. In Fig. 3, we show the results of this clustering method, elucidating 7 different Li3N configurations, which we named based on the unique structural moieties resulting from the interaction of the N atom with the Li atoms. The seven named Li3N are dubbed (a) the square procession, (b) the distorted square procession, (c) the single free, (d) the concealed procession, (e) the shared corner squares, (f) the Li zip, and finally (g) the triangle-square. Square Procession. Representing the most abundant Li3N structures (Fig. S2a), these clusters of structures are so-called due to the unique six Li atom structure, forming a 2 × 3 Li row coordinating with the subsurface/buried N atoms. Four such clusters are shown in Fig. 3, with an average surface nitride formation energy of −2.42 eV, with all identified clusters lying 0.1 eV within this mean energy. Despite being the most abundant state, this structure type is associated with the lowest mean surface nitride formation energy (Fig. S2b and Table S1). Distorted Square Procession. With a mean energy of −2.47 eV, the distorted square procession represents a configuration akin to the square procession. However, the coordination between the N atoms and the 2 × 3 Li row is not as clean, resulting in a distortion of the Li atoms and the N atoms that are not completely buried. Single Free. Progressing in mean energy from the distorted square procession structures with an average energy −2.73 eV, these clusters of structures are characterized by a single buried N atom, coordinating almost randomly with Li atoms. Its name comes from the single N atom that is always observed to coordinate loosely with Li atoms on the surface. Conceal Procession. Similar to the square procession, the concealed procession presents a 2 × 3 Li structure coordinated by subsurface N atoms. However, this cluster shows much closer coordination than in the square procession, aided by the presence of an additional Li atom, which completely conceals the N atoms. This unique configuration results in a much more stable average energy of −2.79 eV. Shared Corner Squares. Unlike any of the square procession configurations, the shared corner square configurations are a seven-Li structure in which four Li atoms each coordinate in a square-like structure with a subsurface N atom. The two squares are joined by a common Li atom, thus giving these clusters their name. The average surface nitride formation energy for this group is −2.87 eV. Li Zip. Having structures most similar to the shared-corner square, this surface Li3N configuration is also characterized by seven Li atoms that coordinate to bury the N atoms. It derives its name from the unique displacement of the shared Li atom, which results in three Li atoms across the structure, having a high surface nitride formation energy of −2.94 eV. Triangle-Square. Representing the other side of the shared corner squares configuration, these structures are characterized by a separation of the N atoms to form a square of Li atoms burying one N atom and a triangle of Li atoms burying the other. This class of structures is the most stable, presenting the lowest surface nitride formation energy of −2.99 eV. 3.2.3 PD effects on energetics of nitride formation We turn to an assessment of the effect of PD on surface nitride formation’s energetics. Here, we use Eq. (7) to calculate the interaction energy, the net energy of the system after all individual components are removed, and Eq. (5) to calculate the equivalent surface nitride formation energy (NF) after removal of PD to allow comparison with our baseline. In Fig. 4, we compare the interaction energies and NF energies between species with critical benchmarks for other competing behaviors in the system. In particular, we look at how PD-induced surface nitride formation compares to N2 adsorption, PD-free/baseline surface nitride formation within the NN and NNN neighborhood regimes, and finally the most stable PD-assisted adsorption calculated in previous work. PDs are arranged within each plot by their minimum energy from highest to lowest. Looking at the surface nitride formation energy within the NN regime (Fig. 4a), we find that the PD increases the favorability of when compared to the most thermodynamically favorable baseline nitrides in both neighborhood regimes. Nitride formation is also favored over nitrogen adsorption, although competition with adsorbed N2 phases formed by the influence of PD could be challenging. Within the NNN regime (Fig. 4b), the formation of nitride appears to be thermodynamically favored over the competing nitrogen interactions considered for most investigated PD species. This difference in behavior across the two neighborhood regimes is consistent with observed behaviors with the baseline nitride, where, similarly to what we see here, the thermodynamics of surface nitride formation is stronger within the NNN regime. We note that these surface nitride formation energies exist for systems that are stabilized only through the presence of the PD. We next consider the interaction energy, which is a metric for the overall stability of the system. We find that in both the NN regime (Fig. 4c) and the NNN regime (Fig. 4d), the interaction energies of the Li-PD-N2 system is much more negative than any of the pure Li-N2 energies. This confirms that the presence of PD during the PD-induced formation of Li3N does not destabilize the system with respect to the PD-absent system. The prediction of more thermodynamically favorable Li3N(Fig. 4(a–b)) in the presence of a PD-stabilized lithium-nitrogen system (Fig. 4(c-d)) is in line with experimental studies by McFarlene et al. [19], who showed increased nitride formation on lithium in the presence of humidified N2 and may underlie the increased Faradaic efficiencies observed in lithium-mediated systems when trace water and oxygen are introduced into the electrolyte [45,46]. 3.2.4 Comparative energetics for the PD-induced protonation The protonation of Li3N during or after its formation is an important intermediate step to NH3 formation in the lithium-mediated process. In this section, we explore the thermodynamics of the protonated configurations evolved during our structural relaxation. We do this by adsorbing a single hydrogen in the PD-absent systems Li3N that we established during our baseline study to provide a new comparative baseline for the thermodynamics of PD-induced protonation. Similar to our nitride systems, we allow for comparison between the PD-induced protonated system and the PD-absent one by getting the energy of the Protonated configuration deprotonated PD. For these systems, we can thus define the protonation energy which we can find using: (8) where E N − N H is the protonation energy, n the number of nitrogen atoms, E s l a b − N − N H is the DFT energy of the nitrogen atom (N) and a protonated nitrogen atom (NH) on the lithium slab, E s l a b is the energy of the lithium slab alone, is the DFT energy of an isolated nitrogen molecule, and is the DFT energy of an isolated hydrogen molecule. As we did not find doubly protonated ( or NNH2) configurations, we find Eq. (8) sufficient to provide a comparison to PD-absent protonation. In Fig. 5, we show how protonation of Li3N due to proton transfer from PD compares to protonation from a free proton H. Fig. 5a shows the protonation energy in the NN scheme. We find that for all PDs studied, the minimum energy configuration due to proton transfer from the PD is less thermodynamically favored than protonation from the free proton (black line). This observation is shown to be the same for the NNN scheme (Fig. 5b), within which fewer PDs are observed to experience proton transfer. Perhaps more interestingly, when looking at the interaction energy for these protonated in the NN scheme (Fig. 5c), we find that some of these configurations – despite being the most thermodynamically stable system for their respective PD – are destabilized with respect to protonation from a free hydrogen atom. Although this is expected for molecules without protons such as ethane and propane, we find this also to be the case for PDs like ethanol and 1-propanol that have been shown to be active in LiMEAS [40–42]. In the NNN regime (Fig. 5d ), we find propane and ethane still show destabilization of their protonated systems with respect to free hydrogen protonation. However, for all other species, we find a larger and more negative interaction energy compared to the PD-free system. Aggregating the results of Fig. 5, we deduce that PD-induced protonation of Li3N is primarily stabilized by the presence of PD through the interaction energy. 3.3 Understanding PD-induced behavior 3.3.1 PD-induced slab reorganization We seek now to understand the source of the PD’s nitride stabilizing effect on surface nitride formation and gain insight into the comparative instability of the protonated structures. Motivated by the plethora of emergent nitride structures discussed previously, we hypothesize that the presence of PD could induce the reorganization of lithium atoms to facilitate more stable surface nitride formation. We tested this hypothesis by using the average positional displacement of freely moving atoms in our final configuration when compared to a reference slab as a metric to quantify the degree of slab reorganization. We calculate this average displacement using: (9) Two-Layer Displacement = 1 N ∑ i = 1 N ( x i − x 0 ) 2 + ( y i − y 0 ) 2 + ( z i − z 0 ) 2 where ( x , y , z ) i represent atomic positions in our final configuration and ( x , y , z ) 0 represent atomic positions in our reference slab. We compare the final configurations with the pristine slab (Fig. 6a). Additionally, we consider displacements in the first and second atomic layers separately in addition to their average, which we dub the 2-layer displacement. We verify the physicality of this metric by comparing it to the surface energy of the lithium slab, calculated after obtaining the energy of the relaxed lithium slab without any adsorbates. In Fig. 6b, we observe that for all three displacement metrics, the surface energy increases as the atoms in the slab undergo more displacement. In line with our intuition, surface atoms experience more displacement on average than atoms in the second layer, and the 2-layer displacement lies between the two groups. With both references across all displacement types, we find that the surface energy of the PD-reorganized slab is much lower than that of the pristine slab, lending credence to the need for the PD to stabilize the slab. It is also worth noting that with reconstructions ranging from 0.2 Å to 1.2 Å, Li-slab atoms are displaced on average 6%–40% of the slab’s lattice constant. To elucidate the effect of reconstruction on thermodynamics, we consider in Fig. 7 any statistically significant correlations between the average 2-layer displacement of each proton donor species and their energetics. Within the NNN regime (Fig. 7a), we find a strong negative correlation (−0.926) between the interaction energy and the average 2-layer displacement compared to the pristine slab. This suggests, perhaps counterintuitively, that configurations with the greatest slab reorganization are the most stable. To understand this more clearly, we look at how the average displacements when compared to similar baselines correlate with the surface nitride formation energy within the same neighborhood regime (Fig. 7b). We find a moderately positive correlation (0.64) between the surface nitride formation energy and the displacement of the free atoms. From this we deduce that the stability of the underlying nitride structure decreases with increasing displacement compared to that of baseline systems. Considering both results in tandem suggests that while the nitrides formed by slab reorganization may not be as stable (from NF energy), the PD manages to stabilize the system through the interaction energy, allowing the Li slab to accommodate greater degrees of reorganization to form a nitride. Within the NN regime, we find only a moderately negative correlation (−0.645) between the interaction energy and the displacement of the free atoms (Fig. 7c). Consistent with the NNN regime, albeit to a lesser extent, the PD appears to stabilize larger displacements through the interaction. Unlike the NN regime, we find a moderate negative correlation (−0.647) between the surface nitride formation energy and the average atomic displacement compared to comparable baseline slabs (Fig. 7d). This correlation indicates increasing stability of the underlying nitride with increasing slab reorganization, again reinforcing the idea that PD-induced reorganization of the lithium slab is a driver for surface nitride formation. For the protonated structures, performing similar analysis shows a strongly positive correlation (0.748) between the protonation energy and the 2-layer displacement in the NN scheme. However, this corresponds to a weak correlation (−0.336) with the interaction energy. This suggests that while increasing the average displacement of free atoms may lead to more stable protonated forms, the formation of these protonated structures is not solely due to the PD’s influence on the Li slab. This is further emphasized in the NNN regime where we find a weakly positive correlation (0.508) between the protonation energy and the 2-layer displacement corresponding to a moderately negative interaction energy correlation of −0.661. The core insight of these correlations is that the PD-induced reorganization of the Li surface has a much stronger effect on stabilizing the formation of nitrides than it does facilitating proton transfer (see Fig. S3). 3.3.2 PD effects on nitrogen reduction The dissociative reduction of nitrogen from its elemental state (oxidation state 0) to its trivalent state (oxidation state −3) during the formation of its nitride phase is deemed to be a crucial step in electrochemical ammonia synthesis via a dissociative pathway. Thus, we performed Bader charge analysis on the final configurations to understand how the presence of the PD affects nitrogen reduction during surface nitride formation and elucidate any correlations with the PD’s slab reorganization effects. In Fig. 8, we consider how the charge on both nitrogen atoms change with increasing slab reorganization [70]. For the NNN regime, we find that the two-layer displacement is strongly correlated (−0.760) with the minimum charge gained on any of the N atoms (electrophilic N) (Fig. 8a). Similar but stronger correlation strengths are found for both the charge gained on the nucleophilic N atom (−0.945; Fig. 8b) and the total charge gained across both N atoms (−0.952; Fig. 8c). This suggests that increasing the two-layer displacement, which is a proxy for the degree of surface reconstruction, results in an increased reduction of the N atom on the Li surface, providing a direct link for the effect of PD on nitrogen reduction. In the NN regime (Fig. S4), there is only a moderately negative correlation (−0.540) between the charge on the least reduced nitrogen and the Li slab (Fig. S4a). However, in the most reduced nitrogen atom (Fig. S4b), we find a slightly stronger negative correlation between the nitrogen charge and the reorganization of the Li slab. In both regimes, we see that, as the reorganization increases, the degree of nitrogen reduction in the underlying nitride makes it more trivalent and thus more similar to nitrogen in the bulk nitride. We speculate that the weakening correlation in the NN regime may be a result of destructive interactions between nitrogen and the PD’s reorganization effect. These findings establish a mechanistic link between PD-induced surface reconstruction and enhanced Li3N stability. Specifically, we find that greater slab reorganization correlates strongly with increased electron transfer to nitrogen atoms, facilitating their reduction towards a trivalent ( ) state. This deeper reduction is expected to strengthen Li–N bonding interactions, thereby stabilizing the resulting nitride phase more effectively than on unreconstructed or less distorted surfaces. We additionally find that all three charge parameters are strongly positively correlated with the interaction energy (Fig. 8(d–f)) with the electrophilic, nucleophilic and total 2N charge gained having correlation strengths of 0.733, 0.909 and 0.917 respectively. This tells us that systems with more negative interaction energies are associated with a more reduced N. Alternatively, the greater the degree of reduction of N atoms, the more stable the system. As N atom reduction occurs primarily due to its interaction with the Li surface, this means that the formation of a more energetically stable PD-induced Li3N drives greater reduction of N on the surface, which further stresses the importance of PD in this interaction. 3.4 Kamlet–Taft parameters as predictors for PD behavior and resulting outcomes So far, we have shown that PD increases the stability of Li3N for all PDs (Fig. 4) and only stabilizes the protonation of Li3N for certain PDs (Fig. 5). We have successfully linked this influence to the PD’s ability to induce reconstruction on the Li surface (Fig. 7), forcing it into structural configurations favorable for Li3N formation with reduced N reduction(Fig. 8). In this section, we seek to concretize our understanding of the effect of PD as a driving force for Li3N formation, Li3N protonation and finally its decomposition in the presence of dissociated N atoms. We look to the chemistry of these PDs to understand how they affect these phenomena of interest. We use the Kamlet–Taft parameters as a starting point of this discussion, as our previous work has shown them to be descriptors of LiMEAS activity [41] and a strong predictor of N2 bond length elongation in cases where protonation of N2 occurred [47]. With the Kamlet–Taft α parameter being a measure of a PD’s hydrogen-bond-donating strength, we expect that it will remain a strong predictor for proton transfer activity on Li3N ( ∗ H + 2 N → N + NH ∗ ). We use the interaction (Int.) energy as the starting point for our analysis for Li3N formation, Li3N protonation, and dissociation of PD in Li3N. We perform additional analyses on the surface nitride formation (NF.) and protonation energies where appropriate, and we also try to understand correlations between the PD’s chemistry and nitrogen charge across the surface. We expand our suite of descriptors of PD chemistry to capture a diverse range of PD behavior. To account for the effects of polarity, we explore correlations with the Kamlet–Taft π ∗ [71] and the Dimroth and Reichardt E T [72,73]. In addition to the Kamlet–Taft α which serves as a measure of PD acidity, we include the Gutmann Acceptor number (AN), a measure of Lewis acidity [74,75], and other acidity measures such as the acid dissociation constant (pKa). We augment our parameter list for basicity measures, too, adding to the Kamlet–Taft β parameter, the Gutmann Donor number (DN) [74,75]. Consistent with our previous correlation analysis, we classify correlation values of magnitude from 0 to 0.3 to be a negligible correlation, between 0.3 and 0.5 to be a low correlation, between 0.5 and 0.7 to be moderate, between 0.7 and 0.9 to be strong, and above 0.9 to be nearly perfect [47]. 3.4.1 Correlations with Li3N formation Exploring the correlation between the interaction energy of the NNN configuration with PD intact and the parameters of interest, we find a strong negative correlation (−0.815) associated with the Kamlet–Taft beta β parameter (Fig. 9a). This means that the interaction energy decreases as the β parameter increases, making the system more stable. As β indicates hydrogen bond-accepting behavior, we ascertain that the stability of the underlying Li3N through the interaction energy increases with increasing Kamlet–Taft β . Similarly, strong correlations are found with other measures of bond basicity considered, with a strong negative correlation found to exist with the Donor Number (DN) of −0.838 (Fig. 9b). This suggests that the stabilizing influence of PD on Li3N formation is not exclusively linked to the hydrogen-bond acceptance activity of the PD, but also the electron pair donation activity of the PD. These correlations highlight an interaction that is facilitated primarily through electron transfer, with the nucleophilicity of the PD being an intervening factor. This point is further reinforced when looking at the correlations between the interaction energy and the Kamlet–Taft α parameter, an indicator of hydrogen-bond donation behavior. Here, perhaps expectedly, we find a low and statistically insignificant correlation of −0.458 between α and the interaction energy(Fig. 9c). However, in contrast, strong correlations are found with measures of electron pair acceptance such as the Gutmann Acceptor Number (AN), with a negative correlation of −0.766 and a positive correlation with the acid dissociation constant pKa (0.738). This suggests that increasing acidity, either by increasing the acceptor number or by lowering the pKa, results in more negative interaction energy, thus resulting in more stable underlying nitrides Li3N. Synthesizing this result leads to the assessment that the nucleophilic properties of PD are important to facilitate the stabilization of Li3N through the interaction energy. From the analysis to date, we are led to believe that both the electrophilic (acceptance of electron pairs) and the nucleophilic (donation of electron pairs) properties of PD are necessary to facilitate stable formation Li3N. The moderately negative correlation (−0.658) between the interaction energy and the Kamlet–Taft pi parameter π further suggests that increasing the polarity of the PD results in a higher negative interaction energy, thus stabilizing Li3N. A similarly moderately negative correlation (−0.645) is found with Dimroth–Reichardt E T , another measure of hydrogen bond polarity. Combining all of these findings suggests that highly amphoteric PDs are necessary for stable Li3N formation due to their ability to receive and transfer electron pairs. The correlation with polarity may thus be as a result of the resultant polarity arising from the presence of these highly acidic and basic centers. We continue to build our understanding of the system by expanding our analysis to the nitride formation energy, which highlights the stability of Li3N formed without the PD. Here, we find low and statistically insignificant correlations between the chosen measures of basicity, the Kamlet–Taft β (0.366) and the Gutmann Donor number (0.313). On the other hand, when considering measures of acidity, we find moderate correlations of 0.629 with the Gutmann Acceptor Number, −0.692 with the pKa, and 0.649 with the Kamlet–Taft α . From these correlations, we see that increasing AN or α results in more positive nitride formation energy, thus creating a less stable Li3N in the absence of the PD. This is the same trend witness for increasing pKa (reducing acidity) which also results in lower nitride formation energy. We find a moderately positive correlation between the polarity parameter π and the nitride formation energy (0.627), suggesting that increasing the polarity also destabilizes underlying Li3N. The above results highlight the crucial role of the PD in Li3N formation. Here, too, the unifying concept across the α , AN, and pKa lies within the electrophilicity of the PD. Fig. 4 clearly shows that the Li3N produced in the presence of the PD are more stable than that produced in their absence. We also showed in Fig. 7 that this increase in stability owes to the increased surface reconstruction. Our analysis of the interaction energy correlations with the nitride formation energy correlations show an inverse relationship across the acidity parameters. That is, increasing the acidity of the PD results in reducing stability of the reconstructed Li3N configurations. However, these Li3N can exist because in the presence of the PD, the interaction energy creates a more stable system. As we find correlations with the measures of acidity and polarity to persist across both the interaction energy and the nitride formation energy whilst correlations with measures of basicity only exist through the interaction energy, we hypothesize then that the acidity of the PD, through its electrophilicity governs the formation of the Li3N whether it be through surface reconstruction or some other unexplored mechanism. This created Li3N is then stabilized by the PD through its basicity, thus requiring the amphoteric PD. Unfortunately, we find no direct and statistically significant correlations between any of the PD parameters and our measure of slab reconstruction, the 2-layer displacement. Similarly, no correlation effects are found between the PD and measures of N reduction (total 2N charge, Electrophilic N charge, Nucleophilic N charge). However, as the 2-layer displacement and the measures of N reduction are shown to be correlated to the 2-layer displacement and the interaction energy, this merely shows that some of these variables may be confounding factors, or that the correlation between the PD’s chemistry and these resultant effects (2-layer displacement and measures of N reduction) may be more complex and nonlinear. However, the dependence of the Li3N nitride formation energy on acidity measures suggests that its formation would occur through some acid-catalyzed mechanism. This could be a result of an electron-withdrawing interaction from N atoms to make them more electrophilic, thus promoting their subsequent electron-withdrawing interaction with the Li. This electrophilic interaction within the vicinity of the N atom would, therefore, induce the reconstruction of the Li surface to promote the formation of Li3N, which explains the strong correlation between the two variables but not with the PD chemistry. Finally, the reduction of N through its interaction with the Li surface via the reconstruction mechanism would create an unstable surface — as the reconstruction would create higher Miller index surfaces on Li with dangling bonds. The adsorptive interaction with the PD would then stabilize these bonds. This task would be more suited towards PDs with available electron pairs that can interact with the now deficient Li surface in electron-donation interactions, thus explaining the high correlations found with the measures of basicity. Precedence for both reaction mechanisms exists already in the literature. We see that in the acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of nitriles to form carboxylic acid, electron transfer from nitrogen to a deficient hydrogen forms a crucial intermediate step of the reactions [76–80]. In a similar vein, nitrile reduction with organometallic catalysts (R-M-X where R is an alkyl group and M is a metal) such as an organolithium or organomagnesum reagent to form aldehydes requires a similar electrophilic attack of the cyano-group, freeing up the nitrogen to engage in an electron-donating interaction with the electron-deficient metal, similar to what we have proposed above [81–85]. The interaction of surfaces with adsorbates whether to induce chemisorption or result in adsorbate-induced surface reconstruction, as we propose through the PD’s electron-donation influence, as seen in related heterogeneous catalysis and surface science principles [86,87]. 3.4.2 Understanding protonation behavior We proceed to correlation analysis between the protonated configurations, where proton transfer occurs to formed Li3N, and the interaction as well as the protonation energy to understand the effect of PD chemistry in driving these interactions. When exploring the interaction energy, we find the strongest correlation with the Kamlet–Taft polarity parameter π , being strongly negative at −0.899. This correlation aligns with that found between the E T and the interaction energy (−0.82) (Fig. 9d). This indicates that increasing the hydrogen-bond polarity of the PD results in more negative interaction energy associated with systems where proton transfer occurs, which is what one would intuit. Considering the measures of acidity, we find stronger correlations specifically with measures of hydrogen bond acidity, α (−0.707) and pKa (0.827) than with AN (−0.689), the primary measure of Lewis acidity (−0.689). We see then that increasing the acidity of the PD, whether by increasing α and AN, or reducing the pKa, results in protonated structures with more negative energies, suggesting again increased stabilization through acidity. For the measures of basicity, we find only moderately negative correlations between the interaction energy and β (−0.507) and DN (−0.588). This suggests that while the nucleophilicity of the PD may play a role in stabilizing the system, the protonation interaction is dominated primarily by the PD’s polarity and how electron-deficient its hydrogen atom is to facilitate the transfer. The correlations between protonation energy and acidity measures reveal only moderate correlations with pKa (−0.633) and α (0.575). This behavior is consistent with that observed for nonprotonated Li3N where increasing the acidity of the proton donor by reducing pKa or increasing α results in a protonated state with more positive energy and thus less stable. However, differing from non-protonated Li3N is the fact that protonated structures in the presence of PD were less stable than protonation of free hydrogen (Fig. 5). Insight into the cause of this deviation can be gleaned from the correlations with the basicity measures. We suggested previously that the electron-donation interaction of PD was the primary mechanism for stabilizing the dangling bonds created on the surface due to its reconstruction [47]. The weaker correlation observed here may suggest an inhibition of its ability to do so in the protonated structure, most likely through the confounding of the interaction due to the PD transfer. 3.4.3 Understanding decomposition behavior We finally explore the formation of altered PD states by similarly looking at whether the chemistry of PD links to the interaction energy of systems in which the PD decomposition occurred due to adverse interactions with N atoms. Unlike our previous analysis for both protonated and non- protonated Li3N configurations, where stronger correlations are found in our exploration of the NNN neighborhood scheme, we find no statistically significant correlation between the interaction energy of altered states in the NNN scheme and any of the parameters of PD chemistry explored. However, when looking at the NN scheme, we find the strongest correlation between the interaction energy and the Gutmann Acceptor Number (−0.77), suggesting that an increase in PD acidity results in lower interaction energies and thus more stable states. This is reinforced by a strongly positive correlation with pKa (0.701) and a strongly negative correlation with E T , with the latter correlation highlighting a similar dependence of the stability of the PD altered state on the PD polarity. The correlation with α is only moderately negative at −0.564, leading us to believe the primary source of the interaction is through electron-pair rather than hydrogen-bond acidity. Finally, the interaction energy of these altered states show moderately negative correlations with the Gutmann Donor Number (−0.647) and β (−0.639). The behavior of the correlations seen here is similar to that governing the protonation behavior of Li3N, where we also found stronger correlations to measures of acidity than to measures of basicity. In line with the explanation outlined there, we are led to believe then that the formation of these PD altered states is made favorable when the PD is too electron-withdrawing, suggesting that an excess of this interaction causes reaction with the N atom, preventing it from engaging in its Li3N formation duties. The main distinguishing feature between correlations of PD chemistry towards the formation of nonprotonated Li3N versus those where the PD undergoes protonation or some other alteration is in the dominating importance of PD basicity over its acidity in cases where Li3N forms. This naturally leads to the hypothesis that systems having acidities that are too high are more likely to engage in interactions detrimental to Li3N formation, whereas those having intermediate acidities with moderate to high basicities would favor Li3N without inhibition. We perform our final analysis on our full dataset to test this hypothesis. We explore the correlations between the measures of basicity and acidity and the minimum interaction energy per PD across our entire dataset. We switch our summary statistic here from the median to the minimum here because we are more interested in the overall thermodynamic drive to a particular PD outcome. Consistent with behaviors in both the protonated and altered states, the correlations of the interaction energy with measures of acidity are shown to be much stronger across both scheme in the NN and NNN scheme (Table S4), with the Acceptor Number being the weakest coordinating acidity parameter at −0.685 in the NN scheme and −0.705 in the NNN scheme. In contrast to correlations with acidity measures, the highest correlations of the interaction energy with PD basicity measures are found with the Donor Number (−0.641) and β (−0.578). In Fig. 10, we project the various PD outcomes into the KT space, drawing inspiration from the work done by Krishnamurthy et al. [41]. For the NN scheme whose decomposed state showed stronger and statistically significant correlations with the interaction energy (Fig. 10a), we show that the Kamlet–Taft parameters are a descriptor of the behavior of PD, particularly highlighting the goldilocks zone 0.48 ≤ β ≤ 0.8 where PD forms Li3N without engaging in protonation or alteration through decomposition. That this zone is only dependent on β , the measure of the basicity of the hydrogen bond, is consistent with our analysis, suggesting that the basicity of the PD is required to stabilize the formation of Li3N, in addition to supporting our hypothesis that extremes in acidity result in Li3N inhibition. Expanding to a neighborhood-agnostic data set results in the introduction of an altered and protonated configuration within this suggested goldilocks zone, challenging our earlier assertion (Fig. 10b). However, we note that even with the introduction of these states into the goldilocks zone, no uninhibited or normal Li3N is formed out of it, highlighting the role of intermediate basicity in promoting the formation of Li3N. The acidity measures were not the only parameters of PD that served as indicators of the formation of decomposed and protonated Li3N. Thus, we turn to Kamlet–Taft π , a measure of hydrogen-bond polarity, to glean insights into how it may interact with basicity to determine the outcome of PD during Li3N formation. In Fig. 10c, we find that we can still make the same separation between the different PD outcomes within the same range of β (0.48 ≤ β ≤ 0.8) with π . After expanding to the neighborhood-agnostic data set (Fig. 10d), we are able to obtain a perfect separation between the Li3N states where PD remains intact and those where other outcomes occur. This suggests that polarity may have a stronger effect in modulating the formation of altered states than the electron-withdrawing behavior. In the very least, our analysis shows that there is a range of β − π where PD can influence Li3N formation without undergoing alteration. We did not find such a zone to exist when considering a similar analysis for AN and DN (See Fig. S7). We round up this work by highlighting that while the formulation of the goldilocks zone only excludes the formation of protonated Li3N, this state may be more desirable in LiMEAS, where the formation of NH3 through rapid protolysis is needed to avoid hydrogen evolution. Furthermore, since our analysis does not consider the effect of the potential and the many complexities of the experimental system, such as the interactions between PD and the solvent, it is probable that the boundaries of this unique region where Li3N formation is encouraged become more malleable. However, our analysis provides a first approximation for the design and selection of solvent components towards the more favorable formation of Li3N post N2 dissociation. 4 Conclusion In this work, we used DFT to explore the effects of 14 proton donor (PD) species on Li3N formation. We show that the absence of PD, Li3N formation from 2 nitrogen atoms is always out-competed by subsurface N2 embedding and sometimes out-competed by surface N2 adsorption. However, the presence of PD species during the formation of Li3N resulted in one of three outcomes; the PD remains intact on forming Li3N, the PD protonates Li3N, or the PD is altered. In cases where the PD remain intact, it was shown to increase the stability of the formation of nitride, making it the most preferred lithium-nitrogen interaction in the system. Exploration of these Li3N configurations showed an increased arrangement of Li atoms, leading us to speculate that the PD influence was to induce surface reconstruction. By introducing the two-layer displacement as a measure of this reconstruction, we were able to draw strong correlations between the stability of the Li-2N-PD system (through the interaction energy) and the degree of surface reconstruction, showing that higher two-layer displacements resulted in more favorable stable systems. Through charge analysis, we further linked this two-layer displacement to the degree of reduction of nitrogen atoms on the Li surface. We drew correlations between Li3N formation and the parameters that govern PD chemistry, showing that PD basicity showed strong correlations with the stability of the overall system. The PD’s acidity and polarity were shown to destabilize the underlying Li3N and were shown to be the primary parameter classes governing the protonation and PD alteration. This allowed us to establish a region in KT β − π space where PDs in the region formed intact Li3N. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-mediated electrochemical ammonia synthesis (LiMEAS) hinges on the formation of lithium nitride (Li3N) from dissociated nitrogen at a lithium surface. Although proton donors (PDs) are known to influence nitrogen activation, their specific role in promoting Li3N formation is still being investigated. Herein, we employ density functional theory (DFT) to examine the effects of 17 PDs on the stability and energetics of Li3N formation. We show that in the absence of PD, Li3N formation is consistently outcompeted by subsurface N2 embedding and, in some cases, by surface N2 adsorption. However, the introduction of PD species yields three distinct outcomes: (i) the PD remains intact during Li3N formation, (ii) the PD protonates Li3N, or (iii) the PD undergoes structural change. Notably, configurations in which the PD remains intact exhibited greater stability compared to subsurface embedding, driven by PD-induced surface reconstruction. We quantify this reconstruction using a two-layer displacement metric and find a strong correlation between the magnitude of displacement and the system’s overall stability. Further charge analyses show that the enhanced Li3N stability correlates with a greater electron transfer to nitrogen. Finally, we link the basicity, acidity and polarity of PD with the results of the formation of nitride, demonstrating that the basicity of PD promotes intact configurations Li3N. In contrast, higher acidity and polarity lead to protonation and alteration of PD. These insights pinpoint a region in the Kamlet–Taft β – π space where PDs remain intact and foster stable Li3N, informing future strategies to design more efficient LiMEAS systems.
